terms.definition: The original amount of money borrowed, before any interest or fees are added.
terms.example: You borrow $20,000 for a car‚Äî$20,000 is your principal amount

terms.definition: Annual Percentage Rate‚Äîthe yearly cost of borrowing, including interest AND fees.
terms.example: APR lets you compare true costs; a 6% rate with fees may have a 7% APR

terms.definition: Credit backed by collateral that the lender can claim if you don't repay.
terms.example: Auto loans, mortgages‚Äîthe car or house is the collateral

terms.definition: Credit not backed by collateral; lender relies on your promise to repay.
terms.example: Credit cards, personal loans, student loans‚Äîhigher interest rates

leftPanel.title: Collateral Affects Everything
paragraphs: Secured credit requires you to pledge an asset. If you fail to pay, the lender can take the asset‚Äîthis reduces their risk.
Unsecured credit has no collateral backing it. The lender has only your promise to repay, increasing their risk.

highlightBox.text: � Lower lender risk = lower interest rates for YOU. Secured loans almost always have lower rates than unsecured loans.

leftColumn.title: � Installment Credit
items: You know exactly when it's paid off

rightColumn.title: � Non-Installment Credit
items: Examples: credit cards, lines of credit

layoutData.title: Strategic Borrowing Can Build Wealth
paragraphs: Not all debt is bad. Borrowing can be a strategic financial decision when it ultimately improves your financial position:
bulletPoints: Education: Student loans may increase earning potential by $500K+ over your lifetime
Housing: Mortgages build equity; you own an asset instead of paying rent forever
Transportation: Auto loans provide reliable transportation for work
Business: Business loans fund ventures that generate income
Emergencies: Some urgent situations (medical, essential repairs) require immediate funds
Appreciating assets: Borrowing for things that gain value over time

keyPoint.text: üéØ Ask yourself: "Will this loan help me earn more, save more, or build wealth over time?"

leftPanel.title: Red Flags for Borrowing
paragraphs: Borrowing should generally be avoided in these situations:

infoCard.title: The Rule of Thumb:
items: Don't borrow for things you consume
If it won't exist in 5 years, don't finance it

layoutData.title: Your Borrowing Decisions Shape Your Future
paragraphs: The decisions you make about borrowing will affect your financial life for years or even decades. Understanding the true cost gives you power:
bulletPoints: Avoid costly mistakes: A bad car loan can cost you thousands more than necessary
Negotiate better terms: Knowledge helps you get lower rates and better deals
Build credit wisely: Strategic borrowing and repayment builds your credit score
Achieve goals faster: Smart borrowing for education or housing accelerates wealth-building
Avoid debt traps: Recognize predatory lending and high-cost options like payday loans
Maintain financial freedom: Keep debt manageable so you have options in life

content.headerTitle: Key Factors That Affect Loan Costs

leftPanel.title: What Determines Your True Cost?
paragraphs: Several factors combine to determine how much you'll actually pay when you borrow money:
Interest Rate: The percentage the lender charges for borrowing money.
Loan Term: Longer terms = lower payments but MORE total interest.
Payment Strategy: Paying more than minimum saves thousands.

highlightBox.text: � On a $20,000 loan, choosing 3 years vs. 6 years could save you $2,000+ in interest.
